#Text=Plymouth ( Massachusetts )
#Text=Plymouth , Massachusetts is located on the South Shore .
#Text=Known as " American 's Hometown , " Plymouth is most famous for being the final landing place of the Pilgrims who arrived on board the Mayflower in 1620 .
#Text=The settlement they established , Plimouth Colony , was one of the earliest successful settlements of Europeans in North America .

#Text=In addition to its obvious historical draws , modern-day Plymouth is a picturesque seaside town with a bustling summer resident population who come back year after year to enjoy its beaches , ponds , and forests .
#Text=Although summer is Plymouth 's peak tourist season , spring ( before Memorial Day ) and fall ( after Labor Day ) can be excellent times to visit .
#Text=These bumper seasons are less crowded and certainly more comfortable temperature-wise .

#Text=Spring has mild temperatures and flowers in bloom , and fall has beautiful New England foliage , warm days with cool nights , and different events to explore , such as observing a cranberry harvest .
#Text=Understand
#Text=In area , Plymouth is the largest town in the state of Massachusetts , covering about 100 square miles ( 259 km Â² ) .

#Text=Although the center of tourist activity is in Plymouth 's historic downtown and waterfront areas , the rest of the town is divided into many smaller villages such as Chiltonville , Manomet , Cedarville , North Plymouth , and West Plymouth .
#Text=Although somewhat homogeneous on the surface , each village has its own unique characteristics which makes it worth venturing outside the harbor-side to visit .
#Text=North Plymouth , for example , was once home to the Cordage Company , the largest rope-maker in the world .
#Text=Cordage employed many Italian and Portuguese immigrants who settled in company housing in this part of town , which many of their descendants still proudly call home .
#Text=The Holy Ghost Festa , a major holiday for Portuguese of Azorean descent , is still widely celebrated in North Plymouth each summer .
#Text=Plymouth still has many residents who can trace their ancestry to the original Mayflower passengers and/or Native American tribes .
#Text=Plymouth receives many visitors who are interested in researching their own colonial ancestry , and provides several key resources for doing so .
#Text=The General Society of Mayflower Descendants Library is the recognized authority on Pilgrim ancestry and has plenty of resources to assist you .
#Text=Plymouth Public Library also maintains a large room dedicated to genealogy .

#Text=It should go without saying that Plymouth residents feel Thanksgiving Day belongs to them ; after all , the holiday commemorates a feast shared by the surviving Mayflower passengers and local Native Americans following the Pilgrims ' first harvest in 1621 .

#Text=That said , Thanksgiving in Plymouth is n't celebrated that much differently than in most places ; local activities include a morning parade through town and a local high school football game between cross-town rivals Plymouth North and Plymouth South .
#Text=For tourists , Plimouth Plantation offers a Thanksgiving Dinner on location at their site with the opportunity to learn more about the facts and fictions surrounding the historical event .
#Text=Since 1970 , the United American Indians of New England ( UAINE ) have observed the National Day of Mourning on Thanksgiving Day .
#Text=Observance takes place annually at noon on Cole 's Hill , acknowledging European settlement as the beginning of the genocide and forcible relocation of millions of Native Americans .

#Text=As a final note , " Plimoth " , the old English spelling , is sometimes used to denote a historic site ( e.g. Plimoth Plantation ) , while town sites will be spelled with the modern spelling , " Plymouth " ( e.g. Plymouth Town Hall ) .
#Text=Keep this in mind to avoid confusion if you notice signage such as the exit maker on Route 3 that helpfully reads , " Plymouth / Plimoth Plantation . "
#Text=Get in
#Text=Plymouth makes an excellent day trip ( or several days ' trip ) when exploring the Boston , Providence , or Cape Cod areas .
#Text=By car
#Text=Plymouth covers the entire southern end of Route 3 , extending from Exit 7 along Route 44 to Exit 2 approaching Sagamore and the Cape Cod Canal .
#Text=The historic section of Downtown Plymouth is accessed via Exit 6A .
#Text=Metered parking is available downtown at both public lots and on street .
#Text=The lots often have ticketing machines while street spots have individual meters .
#Text=All parking fills up quickly during summer tourist season and during events such as festivals and parades .
#Text=Get an early start or plan to do a lot of circling to find a spot .
#Text=From Boston and points north : Plymouth is about an hour south of Boston , Massachusetts via Interstate 93 South to Route 3 South .
#Text=Traffic is notorious during weekday rush hours , especially in the summer months where Route 3 is congested with vacationers heading south past Plymouth towards Cape Cod .
#Text=Travel in off-peak hours is strongly advised for an enjoyable and timely trip .

#Text=Route 3A , a two-lane back road which runs parallel to Route 3 from Boston down through the South Shore and directly through Plymouth , was the original road from Plymouth to Boston prior to the national highway system being built in the 1950s .
#Text=Although quite scenic , it is a lengthy drive and not typically worth traveling the entire route .
#Text=From Providence , Rhode Island and points west :
#Text=Plymouth is connected to the west via Route 44 , which runs into the western part of Plymouth through Carver .
#Text=Major interstates to the west such as Interstate 95 connect somewhat haphazardly with Plymouth via I93/Route 3 on the more northern part of I95 , and I495/Route 44 on the more southern end .
#Text=From Cape Cod and points south :
#Text=Plymouth connects to the Cape via Route 6 over the Sagamore Bridge , which turns into Route 3 North .
#Text=It is also accessible via Route 28 on the Cape , which goes over the Bourne Bridge .
#Text=From Bourne , you can take Route 6 to connect to Route 3 North , or continue north on I495 to Route 44 .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Plymouth Municipal Airport ( PYM ) , 246 South Meadow Road .
#Text=This airport is home to over 170 aircraft , most of which are one to ten seat , single or twin engine planes .
#Text=Although the airport mainly serves pilot hobbyists and Cessna-style aircraft , Boston Med Flight , the State Police Air Wing , and the Plymouth County Fire Plane are also based there .
#Text=For those who do n't wish to pilot themselves into town , travelers arriving by plane usually land at Boston 's Logan International Airport ( BOS ) .
#Text=Coach bus and MBTA rail connections can be made from Boston Logan to the Plymouth area .
#Text=Other travelers may elect to arrive at Rhode Island 's T.F. Green Airport ( PVD ) as flights are often cheaper , but there are no direct public transit options to Plymouth from Warwick .
